CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: However , P2 with thiophene spacer between two large units 8 and BDT has poor solubility due to more planar conformation and stronger interchain interactions caused by smaller torsion angle. To our surprise , P3 with three solubilizing n-alkyl groups also has poor solubility probably due to strong interchain interactions. Replacing n-dodecyl in P3 with 2-decyltetradecyl group significantly enhance solubility of P4. P5 and P6 also have good solubility. Molecular weights of the polymers were determined by gel permeation chromatography ( GPC ) using polystyrene standards as calibrants. The polymers P1 and P4-P6 show numberaverage molecular weight ( M n ) of 12^250 , 9934 , 5714 , and 10^053 , with polydispersity indices ( M w / M n ) of 1.30 , 1.43 , 1.71 , and 1.56 , respectively ( Table 1 ). The GPC measurements for P2 and P3 are not carried out due to their low solubility. The thermal properties of the polymers were determined by thermogravimetric analysis ( TGA ) under nitrogen ( Figure 2 ). The decomposition temperature ( T d ) at 5% weight loss for P3-P6 are above 330 °C , while P1 and P2 exhibit lower Td(below 300 °C ) ( Table 1 ). Optical Properties. The UV-vis absorption and photoluminescence ( PL ) spectra of P1-P6 were measured in CHCl 3 ( ca. 10^-6 M ) solution and in thin films , and the results are red - shifted 88 and 112 nm respectively , relative to monomer 4b ( Figure S1 , Supporting Information ) due to increased conjugation. Compared to homopolymer P6 , all copolymers P1-P5 exhibit red - shifted absorptions and smaller optical bandgaps in solution and in film. Broad absorption bands located in the visible region were observed for the solution and film of P1 ( Figure 4 ). The absorbance maximum for P1 in solution is 496 nm. The absorption spectrum of P1 in film exhibits red - shift and distinct shoulder peak at ca. 540 nm , which are probably related to the formation of molecular aggregates owing to the strong interchain interactions. The absorption maxima of P2 in solution and in film are red - shifted 14 and 32 nm relative to that of P1 , respectively , thanks to its more planar conformation and increased conjugation. P3 and P4 exhibit almost same absorption profile in solution and in film. Compared to P1 and P2 , P3 and P4 exhibit relatively narrow and blue - shifted absorption band in solution and in film. P5 in solution and in film exhibits absorbance maxima at 503 and 524 nm , which are shifted 20 nm to the red relative to those of P4 , suggesting a more planar conformation. The trend in emission spectra of P1-P6 in solution and in film resembles that in their absorption spectra.

Let's think step by step.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| P1 |
| P2 |
| P3 |
| P4 |
| P5 |
| P6 |
| Homopolymer P6 |
| Monomer 4b |

The given paragraph mentions several material names throughout it. The above table lists all the material names identified from the paragraph.

Please remove entities that do not clearly refer to "Material name" and present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| P1 |
| P2 |
| P3 |
| P4 |
| P5 |
| P6 |

The paragraph mentions several material names, which are clearly identified and listed above in the table. Other entities such as "homopolymer P6" and "monomer 4b" are also material names in this context.

Paragraph: However , P2 with thiophene spacer between two large units 8 and BDT has poor solubility due to more planar conformation and stronger interchain interactions caused by smaller torsion angle. To our surprise , P3 with three solubilizing n-alkyl groups also has poor solubility probably due to strong interchain interactions. Replacing n-dodecyl in P3 with 2-decyltetradecyl group significantly enhance solubility of P4. P5 and P6 also have good solubility. Molecular weights of the polymers were determined by gel permeation chromatography ( GPC ) using polystyrene standards as calibrants. The polymers P1 and P4-P6 show numberaverage molecular weight ( M n ) of 12^250 , 9934 , 5714 , and 10^053 , with polydispersity indices ( M w / M n ) of 1.30 , 1.43 , 1.71 , and 1.56 , respectively ( Table 1 ). The GPC measurements for P2 and P3 are not carried out due to their low solubility. The thermal properties of the polymers were determined by thermogravimetric analysis ( TGA ) under nitrogen ( Figure 2 ). The decomposition temperature ( T d ) at 5% weight loss for P3-P6 are above 330 °C , while P1 and P2 exhibit lower Td(below 300 °C ) ( Table 1 ). Optical Properties. The UV-vis absorption and photoluminescence ( PL ) spectra of P1-P6 were measured in CHCl 3 ( ca. 10^-6 M ) solution and in thin films , and the results are red - shifted 88 and 112 nm respectively , relative to monomer 4b ( Figure S1 , Supporting Information ) due to increased conjugation. Compared to homopolymer P6 , all copolymers P1-P5 exhibit red - shifted absorptions and smaller optical bandgaps in solution and in film. Broad absorption bands located in the visible region were observed for the solution and film of P1 ( Figure 4 ). The absorbance maximum for P1 in solution is 496 nm. The absorption spectrum of P1 in film exhibits red - shift and distinct shoulder peak at ca. 540 nm , which are probably related to the formation of molecular aggregates owing to the strong interchain interactions. The absorption maxima of P2 in solution and in film are red - shifted 14 and 32 nm relative to that of P1 , respectively , thanks to its more planar conformation and increased conjugation. P3 and P4 exhibit almost same absorption profile in solution and in film. Compared to P1 and P2 , P3 and P4 exhibit relatively narrow and blue - shifted absorption band in solution and in film. P5 in solution and in film exhibits absorbance maxima at 503 and 524 nm , which are shifted 20 nm to the red relative to those of P4 , suggesting a more planar conformation. The trend in emission spectra of P1-P6 in solution and in film resembles that in their absorption spectra.

Let's think step by step.

1. Molecular weights of the polymers:
   - P1: Mn = 1.2 × 10^6 g/mol, Mw/Mn = 1.30
   - P4: Mn = 5.7 × 10^4 g/mol, Mw/Mn = 1.56
   - P5: Mn = 9.9 × 10^3 g/mol, Mw/Mn = 1.43
   - P6: Mn = 1.0 × 10^5 g/mol, Mw/Mn = 1.71

2. Decomposition temperature at 5% weight loss:
   - P1: Td < 300 °C
   - P2: Td < 300 °C
   - P3: Td > 330 °C
   - P4: Td > 330 °C
   - P5: Td > 330 °C
   - P6: Td > 330 °C

3. Absorption maxima in solution:
   - P1: 496 nm
   - P2: 482 nm (red-shifted 14 nm relative to P1)
   - P3: Not provided
   - P4: Not provided
   - P5: 503 nm (shifted 20 nm to the red relative to P4)

4. Absorption maxima in film:
   - P1: 540 nm (red-shifted and distinct shoulder peak)
   - P2: 512 nm (red-shifted 32 nm relative to P1)
   - P3: Not provided
   - P4: Not provided
   - P5: 524 nm (shifted 21 nm to the red relative to P4)

The following entities were removed as they do not clearly refer to a material property value:

* "numberaverage molecular weight (Mn)" and "polydispersity indices (Mw/Mn)" are properties, not values.
* "to our surprise" and "significantly enhance solubility" are not material properties.
* "replacing n-dodecyl in P3 with 2-decyltetradecyl group" is a chemical modification, not a material property.
* "strong interchain interactions" is a phenomenon, not a material property.
* "red-shifted 88 and 112 nm respectively" and "relative to monomer 4b" are descriptions, not material properties.
* "compared to homopolymer P6" is a comparison, not a material property.
* "broad absorption bands located in the visible region" is a description, not a material property.
* "absorbance maximum for P1 in solution is 496 nm" is a material property, but it is already listed in the table.
* "absorption spectrum of P1 in film exhibits red-shift and distinct shoulder peak at ca. 540 nm" is a description, not a material property.
* "probably related to the formation of molecular aggregates owing to the strong interchain interactions" is a speculation, not a material property.
* "absorption maxima of P2 in solution and in film are red-shifted 14 and 32 nm relative to that of P1, respectively" are descriptions, not material properties.
* "thanks to its more planar conformation and increased conjugation" is a reason, not a material property.
* "P3 and P4 exhibit almost same absorption profile in solution and in film" is a statement, not a material property.
* "relatively narrow and blue-shifted absorption band in solution and in film" is a description, not a material property.
* "suggesting a more planar conformation" is a speculation, not a material property.
* "trend in emission spectra of P1-P6 in solution and in film resembles that in their absorption spectra" is a statement, not a material property.
